bestBHT.bht: Jesus uses the metaphor of birds and their nests to communicate the importance of a humble and simple life in following Him. The common word for bird in the New Testament highlights the significance of this metaphor. The fact that Jesus may have given a similar response in a different situation speaks to the universal nature of His message. This verse reminds us to let go of worldly comforts and embrace simplicity and humility when we choose to follow Jesus.

Marvin Vincent: Birds [πετεινα] . Strictly, flying fowl. The common word for bird in the New Testament."
Orneon is found in Revelation 18:2; Revelation 19:17, Revelation 19:21; and pthnon, another form for the word in this passage, occurs 1 Corinthians 14:30."
John Gill: And Jesus said unto him, foxes have holes..."
Both the words of this man to Christ, and Christ's answer to him, are exactly the same as in Matthew...
...it is not improbable, that Christ might be accosted in the same manner by another person, at another time and place, and return a like answer to each...
John Wesley: But Jesus said to him — First understand the terms: consider on what conditions thou art to follow me.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus uses a metaphor in this verse to teach a valuable lesson to one who wants to follow Him. By referring to the birds and their nests, Jesus emphasizes the simple, humble life that He leads and requires from his followers. Other parts of the Bible use the same word for bird, highlighting its common usage throughout the New Testament. Additionally, Jesus' response is not unique, suggesting that He may have given similar advice in different situations. This passage reminds us that following Jesus requires a willingness to let go of worldly comforts and embrace a life of simplicity and humility.

Jesus uses a metaphor to teach about the humble life He leads and expects from His followers. The common word for bird in the New Testament is used here, emphasizing its significance. This passage suggests that Jesus may have given a similar response to another person in a different situation. The lesson is clear - to follow Jesus, we must be ready to let go of worldly comforts and embrace simplicity and humility in our lives.

By utilizing the common word for bird in the New Testament, Jesus emphasizes the significance of this metaphor. Furthermore, the fact that He may have given a similar response to another person in a different situation suggests the universality of His message. Ultimately, this verse reminds us that to follow Jesus, we must be willing to let go of worldly comforts and embrace a life of simplicity and humility.
